journal-title-group.journal-subtitle: Processing of Biogenic Material for Energy and Chemistry

title-group.article-title: Biogenic silver-doped mesoporous silica nanoparticles for multifunctional eco-designed textile printing

institution-wrap.institution: Dyeing, Printing and Textile Auxiliary Department

license.license-p: Open AccessThis article is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License, which permits use, sharing, adaptation, distribution and reproduction in any medium or format, as long as you give appropriate credit to the original author(s) and the source, provide a link to the Creative Commons licence, and indicate if changes were made. The images or other third party material in this article are included in the article's Creative Commons licence, unless indicated otherwise in a credit line to the material. If material is not included in the article's Creative Commons licence and your intended use is not permitted by statutory regulation or exceeds the permitted use, you will need to obtain permission directly from the copyright holder. To view a copy of this licence, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.

sec.p: The current study concerns the valorization of waste rice hulls into value-added materials. To achieve this goal, first, the extraction route of mesoporous silica nanoparticles (SiO2NPs) from rice hulls using citric acid as a carbon template was compared with that prepared by conventional methods of incineration only. Both routes were performed at different temperatures of 600 and 700°C, and the fabricated SiO2NPs were studied by N2 physisorption isotherm, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), dynamic light scattering (DLS), and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. The results show the influence of both routes and temperature on the porous structure, surface area, and charge of as-fabricated SiO2NPs. Furthermore, the physico-chemical features of as-prepared mesoporous SiO2NPs were utilized, in a facile and green way, to prepare silver NPs with high anti-microbial activity. The results were validated by the tools of UV-visible, FTIR, XRD, and XPS spectroscopy. Finally, the fabricated silver-doped mesoporous SiO2NPs were used as auxiliary additives through one-pot printing of different types of fabric (i.e., polyester (synthetic fabric), cotton (natural fabric), and cotton/polyester (blended fabric)). The EDX mapping of the pigment-printed fabrics with Ag-doped SiO2NPs exhibited the homogeneous distribution of Ag and Si atoms together with C and O throughout the fabric matrix. Interestingly, the pigment-printed fabrics with Ag-doped SiO2NPs demonstrated superior antibacterial activity, ultraviolet protection factor (UPF), and color characteristics in comparison to the conventional dyeing component.

notes.title: Statement of novelty
notes.p: The subject of the current manuscript is the conversion of waste rice hull into intriguing nanomaterials, specifically mesoporous silica, which is subsequently embellished with silver nanoparticles. The resultant nanoparticles were intended to be additives to textile pigments with a better UV protection factor, superior color characteristics, and antibacterial activity.

notes.title: Supplementary Information
notes.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at https://doi.org/10.1007/s13399-022-03643-2.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to the volume of agricultural production, the agricultural sector in Egypt plays an important role in the national economy. A large amount of waste is produced by this sector every year. Open burning is the most common method of waste disposal. It is estimated that approximately 52% of agricultural waste is burned directly in the fields or in ineffective incinerators [1]. In Egypt, the total agricultural waste produced from all the selected waste types was estimated at 30 million tons/year [2]. As rice is one of the most important crops in the world, the rice hull (RH) is a continuous and abundant source of agricultural waste in agriculture-based countries, such as China, India, and Egypt. Rice grains are made up of about 20 wt.% hulls. The RH causes a waste problem in rice production areas, and the expansion in rice cultivation necessitates the development of new strategies for managing the hulls [3]. Although management of RH is an important issue, recycling and use should be the main goal. Lately, eco-friendly rules have limited the usual burning or disposal of RH in landfills. Nevertheless, open burning is still mostly done in poor and developing countries, creating ecological and health problems [4, 5]. The main components of RH, which is considered one of the most important agricultural residues, are organic compounds (32.7, 20.5, and 21.8 wt.% of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin, respectively) in addition to 15.1, 2.8, and 7.5 wt.% of silica, soluble substances, and moisture, respectively [6]. Consequently, with the high proportion of silica, RH can be utilized as a cost-effective raw material for the production of silica and silicate substances [7].

The combustion of RH produces a new waste known as rice hull ash (RHA) with high silica content. Hence, RH can be considered as an economical and sustainable raw material for producing silica nanoparticles (SiO2NPs). Though the main mineral component of RHAs is silica, it also contains calcium, iron, magnesium, phosphorus, potassium, sodium, and much smaller amounts of other elements [8]. RHAs can be utilized in several sectors, such as the production of concrete [9], activated carbon [10], and adsorbent for the removal of organic dyes [11], phosphates [12], nitrates [13], and heavy metals from wastewater [14]. The utilization of RH and RHA in the preparation of silica is of environmental and economic significance because of the wide applications of SiO2NPs in the information technology, automotive, ceramics, concrete, fine chemistry, and pulp industries thanks to their tunable mechanical, optical, chemical, and physical properties [15, 16]. High-purity silica is typically produced by using synthetic organic precursors. However, this can be a costly, environmentally hazardous, and non-biocompatible technique. On the other hand, biomass containing an inexpensive and copious natural silica supply could be a potential alternative. But, the less ordered structure and impurities could be drawbacks of these natural sources for applications that demand high purity and less particle size distribution. In any case, it would be more practical to use biogenic silica NPs in the textile sector [17, 18].

The quality of the extracted SiO2NPs is influenced by multiple factors like the process of pretreatment (leaching), the combustion (calcination) temperature, and the burning duration. The use of traditional leaching methods in removing mineral impurities from RH by inorganic acids such as HCl, HNO3, and H2SO4 is accompanied by many disadvantages, such as harm to human life and the environment, the necessary use of expensive materials that are resistant to corrosion, and high consumption of water to get rid of the acid, in addition to the necessity of special systems for disposal [19]. Currently, the established environmental laws have led researchers and environmental scientists to the development of technology that makes use of green chemistry principles while investigating bioresources to reduce environmental pollution and achieve a sustainable future for humanity as well. Accordingly, to exploit RH waste as a renewable source of silica and lower the pollution concerns associated with this waste's processing in Egypt, the exploration and development of green chemistry aspects are the goals of this article.

From an environmental point of view, the use of solutions of organic acids such as citric acid instead of inorganic acids in the leaching treatment of RH before the calcination step is a more benign process. This procedure is safe for the life of organisms and more cost-effective. Further, the metal impurities can be eliminated from RH via a chelating reaction between the metal cations and the carboxyl groups (-COOH) of citric acid. As a result, this process can enhance the level of SiO2 purity by reducing or removing the content of inorganic contaminants [6]. Therefore, the method for calcining RH in the presence of organic acids was suggested in the current investigation due to its numerous potential benefits for the economy and the environment.

Due to their unique physical and chemical properties, metal NPs such as silver, gold, zinc, silica, and titanium have been extensively investigated and developed to improve the properties of technical fabrics. Textile fabrics after coloring treatment with metallic NPs have such properties as anti-bacterial, UV-protective activity, super hydrophobicity, flame retardant, self-cleaning, and high color properties. Among diverse metal NPs that have been studied in antibacterial textile finishing, noble metal NPs such as gold and silver NPs are the most commonly used. Consequently, being non-hazardous and able to attack more than 650 bacteria, fungi, and even viruses makes it an ideal candidate for the antimicrobial finishing of textile fabrics [20–22]. In addition, silver NPs have long-term efficacy as they oxidize slowly and sequentially release ions that combine with sulfur-containing proteins involved in bacterial cells that affect cell vitality [23, 24]. Many preceding studies investigated the combined effect of silver and SiO2NPs by combining their properties together through various reactions [25–27]. Nonetheless, more studies of green in situ synthesis of silver-doped SiO2NPs are still needed. As a result, studies are still being conducted on the synthesis of silver NPs using a variety of fast and environmentally friendly techniques to produce particles with high reactivity and extended stability that can be quickly used in industrial settings. In light of this, we performed this work by resorting to a new green method to generate Ag-doped SiO2NPs while investigating the effects of different processing methods of RH waste on the final properties of Ag-doped SiO2NPs. Above and beyond, the newly created silver-doped SiO2NPs are expected to integrate the qualities of silver NPs and SiO2NPs, which will lead to enhancing and increasing the expected financial return for generating these materials and benefiting from them in the industry.

In this work, the purpose is to transform RH waste into intriguing nanomaterials of mesoporous silica embellished with silver NPs. The resultant NPs are intended to be auxiliary additives to textile pigments for a better UV protection factor, superior color characteristics, and antibacterial activity. Accordingly, the first aim is to investigate new extraction methods for the extraction of high-purity mesoporous SiO2NPs from RH using a thermochemical treatment process. In this regard, dry citric acid was used with RH in one pot during the calcination process; to achieve an eco-friendly method and reduce the time and the number of chemicals. The second aim is to research how various SiO2NP physicochemical characteristics, brought about by the investigational extraction techniques, could affect the characteristics of synthetic Ag-doped SiO2NPs. The third aim presents a novel approach to the production of technical fabrics. This section's goal is to investigate the effects of adding Ag-doped SiO2NPs to single-pot silk-screen printing of polyester (synthetic fabric), cotton (natural fabric), and blended fabrics to produce printed fabrics with multifunctional qualities. Printing was done on the surface of the fabrics followed by fixing the dye through polymerization of the binder using the thermo-fixation technique. By contrasting the outcomes from printed fabrics in the presence and absence of Ag-doped SiO2NPs, the impact of these particles on the properties of printed fabrics could be assessed.

sec.title: Material
sec.p: Rice hull (RH) sample was provided by a local Egyptian rice mill. The RHs were washed with tap water to remove dirt and soluble impurities. It was then dried in the ambient air for 48 h followed by dry grinding to obtain a fine powder. Washed and dried RHs were stored in polyethylene bags at room temperature until use. The tested extractions procedures are summarized in Online Resource 1.

Cotton fabric (100 % Scoured, bleached, plain weave, 140 g/m2), polyester fabric (100 % white) plain weave (149 g/m2), and Cotton/polyester blend (CO/PET) fabric (50/50 %, 135 g/m2) were provided by Misr Company for Spinning and Weaving, Mehalla El – Kubra, Egypt. M.D yellow 2G pigment was supplied by Daico for chemical industry, Cairo, Egypt. Ammonium persulfate, as thermal initiator, was purchased from Merck-Germany. Bercolin CPK and Bercolin metal CM were provided as thickening agents and binders, respectively by Berssa-Turkey.

sec.title: Citric acid pre-treatment and calcination
sec.p: The dry citric acid pre-treatment was done in a ceramic crucible by mixing 50 g of RHs and 5 g citric acid. The crucibles are placed in the muffle furnace (Carbolite, CWF 1200, Keison, UK) at 600 and 700°C for 4 h. RHAs were collected and used for pure silica leaching. The same calcination procedures were applied to RHs in the absence of citric acid at the same temperature and duration. SiO2NPs extracted from combustion processing only are encoded by S600 and S700 while SiO2NPs fabricated by the ignition in the presence of citric acid are encoded by SC600 and SC700 at 600 and 700°C, respectively.

sec.title: Biogenic SiO2NPs
sec.p: Here, mb weight of the hulls before and ma weight after burning [28].

sec.title: Fabrication of silver-doped mesoporous silica nanoparticles (Ag-doped SiO2NP)
sec.p: In the present study, the four prepared SiO2NPs were used as both supporter and reducing agent to prepare silver NPs via a simple, direct one-step, and green process. Lyophilized SiO2NPs (2 g) were suspended in 100 mL deionized water and sonicated for 10 min. Sodium hydroxide solution (0.5 M) were added drop wise to the SiO2NP suspension with stirring until pH 10 is reached (sodium hydroxide act as a catalyst). Then the whole solution was heated to 75°C for 10 min. Afterwards, 5 mL volume of 0.05 M silver nitrate solution was added drop wise (about 1 drop/second) to SiO2NPs suspension at 50ºC under strong agitation. After the addition of 1 mL of silver nitrate the solution turned light yellow. When all of the silver nitrate had been added the yellow colloidal silver solution adopted different colors with the four different SiO2NPs, due to the excitation caused by plasmon resonance at the surface of particles. After two min. the entire addition complete and the reaction stopped. All the prepared silver-doped SiO2NPs were dialyzed against distilled water to remove unreacted solutes. The fabricated silver-doped SiO2NPs suspensions were stowed in a transparent vial at room temperature for up to 16 weeks.

sec.title: Printing textile materials via silver-doped SiO2NPs
sec.p: The pigment paste, applied in fabric printing, consists of 50 g/L pigment, 100 g/L binder, 40 g/L thickener, 10 g/L ammonium persulfate, 20 mL/L Ag-doped SiO2NPs (Ag-SC700), and Y distilled water. The printing paste was prepared according to the previous recipe, homogenized, and applied to the surfaces of the fabrics using the flat silk-screen printing technique. The printed fabrics were thermally fixed at 160°C for 6 min. in an automatic thermal oven (Wemer Mathis Co., Switzerland). After fixation, the printed fabrics were washed with cold water, hot water, and cold water, respectively to remove the excess of thickener and unreacted materials in the printed fabrics.

list-item.p: UV-Vis spectroscopy (Cary 50 Probe, Agilent) was employed to measure Surface plasmon resonances of silver-doped SiO2NPs colloidal suspensions.

FTIR spectroscopy (JASCO FTIR 6100 spectrometer, Tokyo, Japan) in the range of 4000-400 cm-1, with 60 scans and a resolution of 4 cm-1, was used to record the FTIR spectra of the differently fabricated samples.

Here, λ = 0.1542 nm for Cu Ka radiation, K = 0.94, β = half-height width of the diffraction peak, and θ = Bragg angle for all lattice planes and the densest crystal peak (111), in Scherrer's case, respectively.

Thermogravimetric and Derivative Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA and DTG) were conducted using a Perkin Elmer STA 6000 with a heating rate 10 °C/min. in a temperature range from 50 to 800 °C under N2 atmosphere.

Elemental analysis of the fabricated SiO2NPs was recorded by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) using a Quanta FEG-250 microscope at a voltage of 10 kV. Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) of produced SiO2NPs and silver-doped SiO2NPs samples was carried out by a JEOL JEM-2100 (Japan), in high resolution.

Quantachrome (USA; Nova 2000 series) device was utilized to estimate the surface area and pore size of the prepared SiO2NPs by applying the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model. Samples were degassed by heating at 150 °C overnight. The physisorption isotherm was conducted using N2 gas at 77 K.
Particle Sizing Systems (Santa Barbara Inc., California, USA) was utilized to estimate the particle size and zeta potential (ζ) of prepared SiO2NPs.

X-ray electron spectroscopy (XPS) was collected on K-ALPHA (Themo Fisher Scientific, USA) with monochromatic X-ray Al K-alpha radiation −10 to 1350 eV spot size 400 μm at pressure 10-9 mbar with full spectrum pass energy 200 eV and at narrow spectrum 50 eV.
Here, K denotes the absorption coefficient, S denotes the scattering coefficient, and R denotes the fraction of light reflected at a wavelength of minimum reflectance or maximum absorbance [29].
The ultraviolet protection factor (UPF) was estimated using a UV-Shimadzu 3101-PC-Spectrophotometer in accordance with the Australian/New Zealand Standard (AS/NZS-4399-1996).

Fastness to washing was measured according to launder-O-meter AATCC Test method 61-2013 [30]. Light, rubbing, and perspiration measurements were done according to the standard methods of AATCC 1993a, AATCC 1993b, and AATCC 1993c, respectively [31].

sec.title: Anti-microbial test
sec.p: The antimicrobial tests of silver-doped SiO2NPs colloidal suspensions under study were carried out qualitatively against four different bacterial species (Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa as Gram-negative (G-) and Bacillus subtilis and Staphylococcus aureus as Gram-positive (G+)), by antimicrobial disk-diffusion agar method according to AATCC Test Method 147-1988. The qualitative test was carried out using solid media (LB agar). Blank paper disks (Schleicher & Schuell, Spain) with a diameter of 4 mm were steeped in 10µL of the tested four Ag-doped SiO2NPs colloidal suspensions and placed on LB agar, previously inoculated with the bacteria. After 48h, the corresponding inhibition zones are measured using slipping calipers of the National Committee for Clinical Laboratory Standards [32].

The antimicrobial activities of pigment printed fabrics, with and without Ag-doped SiO2NPs, were in vitro examined against Staphylococcus aureus (G+ bacteria), Escherichia coli and Klebsiella (G- bacteria) using nutrient agar medium. The antifungal activity of the tested compounds was tested against Candida albicans using Sabouraud dextrose agar medium. The tested sheets of ca. 17 * 17 mm dimensions were placed on the surface of the solidified media and the plates were incubated at 37°C for 16–24 h for bacteria and 48 h for fungi [33].

sec.title: Extraction and characterization of SiO2NPs
sec.p:
The treatment of dissolved sodium silicate with hydrochloric acid enhances the formation and condensation of silanol groups (R3Si-OH), leading to the development of a three-dimensional expanded Si-O-Si matrix [28, 35]. The products were then examined using a variety of analytical instruments, including the N2 physisorption isotherm, EDX, FTIR, TEM, TG, and XRD analyses. RH showed a high LOI due to its major content of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin. As can be seen from Table 1, the LOI was improved by raising the temperature from 600 to 700°C, while the addition of citric acid reduced the LOI at the analogous temperatures. This can be explained based on the citric acid mode of action during the calcination process. In addition, the purity of the prepared SiO2NPs was determined by EDX analysis. Table 1 and Online Resource 2 showed that SiO2NPs prepared by calcination of RH at 600 and 700 °C contained only silica and oxygen elements. On the contrary, SiO2NPs prepared by calcining RH in the presence of citric acid at 600 and 700 °C, besides silicon and oxygen elements, have low carbon content. The dynamic light scattering of the extracted SiO2NPs shows particles of mean diameter ranging from 221.3 to 255.9 nm with negative zeta potentials ranging between-19.36 and-21.51 mV.Table 1

* LOI % as an estimate of the amount of organic matter from differently treated raw RH samples; a(b) Weight %(Atomic %); DLS parameters [mean diameter (Ø), variance (PDI), stnd. deviation (SD), Norm. SD (coefficient of variation from the intensity distribution), R2, and avg. zeta potential (ζ)]; BET parameters [BET surface area (SBET), BJH surface area (SBJH), total pore volume (TPV), and average pore diameter (APD)]

Figure 1(a and b) shows the N2 physisorption isotherm of the fabricated SiO2NPs samples. According to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemists (IUPAC) recommendation, it is convenient to categorize pores in the context of physisorption according to their size: macropores are defined as having a width greater than or equal to 50 nm; mesopores are defined as having a width between 2 nm and 50 nm; and micropores are defined as having a width less than or equal to 2 nm [36]. In view of that, all of the prepared SiO2NP samples can be categorized as mesoporous materials because their average pore diameter is greater than 6 nm (Table 1). All prepared SiO2NPs showed a type IV isotherm expected from mesoporous materials [37]. Adsorption and desorption measurements of S600, S700, SC600, and SC700 showed a large BET surface area (391.61, 370.61, 340.54, and 391.66 m2/g), BJH surface area (314.06, 263.35, 142.61, and 178.56 m2/g), a total pore volume (1.32, 1.53, 0.54, and 0.59 cm3/g), and an average pore diameter (14.09, 16.56, 6.31, and 6.03 nm) resulting from inter particulate holes present between the NPs, respectively (Table 1). However, SiO2NPs prepared by calcination only at 600 and 700 °C show an H1 hysteresis loop with a narrow range of regular mesopores with minimal lattice impacts. On the other hand, SC600 and SC700 displayed an H3 hysteresis loop induced by the lack of limiting adsorption at a high relative pressure (P/P0) provoked by the existence of a non-rigid assemble of lamina-like particles [36, 38]. Following the IUPAC, these variations in the shape of hysteresis loops of SiO2NPs prepared by different routes of calcination are due to the principle that capillary condensation with hysteresis occurs with mesoporous sorbents having an average pore size above 4 nm and controlled by the sorbent texture [37, 39]. This is in good agreement with the surface area and average pore diameter data from the physisorption studies of as-synthesized SiO2NPs.Fig. 1
N2 physisorption isotherm of fabricated mesoporous SiO2NPs (a) S600 & S700 and (b) SC600 & SC700

Depending on the particle density, the DLS technique is the best methodology for determining the particle size of suspensions from 1 nm to approximately 10 μm. Following is a description of each reported value listed in Table 1: Mean diameter (Ø) = Mean diameter from the intensity distribution, Variance (PDI) = Polydispersity index, Standard Deviation (SD) = Standard deviation from the intensity distribution [i.e., SD (%) of the total distribution lies within ± 1σ], and Normalized Standard Deviation (Norm. SD) = Coefficient of variation from the intensity distribution (SD/ Ø) [40]. Accordingly, we can see from the data that there is a correlation between the temperature that is used during the calcination process of RH and the mean diameter of the SiO2NPs that are produced. Thus, the mean diameter of the SiO2NPs increases as the temperature decreases, yet in this situation, citric acid's action is essentially undetectable. In contrast, processing with citric acid produces more pronounced changes in the standard deviation, variance, and normalized standard deviation.

When working with a system, like biogenic extracted SiO2NPs, with a polydispersity index of less than 0.7 and close to 0.3, a high value of the standard deviation can be regarded as acceptable. In this instance, the standard deviation would closely related to the standard distribution (i.e., the width of the peak particle size distribution), which can be inferred from the intensity distribution's coefficient of variation, which is nearly 0.5 [41, 42]. On the other hand, since this is intensity weighted Gaussian distribution, the mean (Ø) and standard deviation (SD) can be used to determine the entire result. Though, the ISO 22412 -2008 for Particle Size Analysis — Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS) recommends that the mean (Ø) and the polydispersity index (PDI) be used to present the findings.

Table 1 clarifies that the characteristic parameters of fabricated SiO2NPs (e.g., LOI, elemental analysis (Online Resource 2), Ø, PDI, SD, R2, avg. ζ, SBET, SBJH, TPV, and APD vary with different routes applied to prepare SiO2NPs (i.e., temperature and method of calcination). Further, the results obtained for surface area and pore volume were higher than those obtained when RH, pre-treated with citric acid, was calcined at 600 °C [35].

TG analysis was also performed to evaluate the calcination routes applied to the RH. Figure 2 shows thermograms of RH and fabricated SiO2NPs samples. For the RH, the first observed weight loss step reached its maximum weight loss (wtloss max) of 8.97 % at 122°C. This stage results from the evaporation of the adsorbed water molecules as well as other volatile components. The second observed weight loss step (pyrolysis) occurred between 226 and 415°C, with a maximum weight loss of 50.41%. The overlapping thermal degradation of hemicellulose, cellulose, and lignin is responsible for the stage in which the organic components are converted to volatiles and ash. This temperature range can be divided into two zones: The first is the active pyrolysis zone, in which the main weight loss occurs. That region can be attributed to the decomposition behaviors of the main components of lignocellulose materials: hemicellulose, cellulose, and lignin to form volatiles and chars. The major weight loss in this zone is mainly attributed to the preliminary decay of hemicellulose and cellulose. The second zone is called the passive pyrolysis zone, where the decomposition process is completed by the conversion of the remaining lignin and the formation of ash [43].Fig. 2
TG and DTG analyses of rice hull (RH) and fabricated mesoporous SiO2NPs

In contrast, only one dominating pyrolysis phase can be seen in the range of 30–200°C in TGA thermograms for as-produced SiO2NPs. This stage, which varies well with the applied calcination route, can be attributed to the volatilization of the adsorbed water molecules [44]. Hence, weight loss at <150°C could be attributed to the removal of water molecules adsorbed on the SiO2NPs, while that loss at higher temperatures could be due to the complete conversion of the remaining silanol groups to siloxane bonds. The weight loss for the S600 and S700 was 22.99 and 19.9 wt.%, respectively, in the temperature ranges of 23–170°C and 29–208°C. Over a temperature range of 37–66°C and 29–126°C, the SC600 and SC700 showed weight losses of 13.10 and 13.19 wt.%, respectively. In terms of the approach used during the calcination procedure, SiO2NP samples made without citric acid showed higher weight loss in this region, indicating larger surface areas and higher porosity in comparison to those extracted with citric acid, with smaller spherical particles and less porosity as discussed previously. Thermal stability after this phase of weight loss is another evidence confirming the complete fabrication of pure mesoporous SiO2NPs [28, 45, 46]. It is clear from the obtained results that the role of dry mixing of citric acid with RH before calcination was as a carbon template to control the growth of particles, agglomerations, and pores structure. Similar results were obtained when citric acid was dry mixed with limestone and dolomite before calcination to form porous, MgO-stabilized CaO pellets [47].

The molecular structure of the used raw RH and prepared SiO2NPs in this study can be traced by FTIR analysis as shown in Fig. 3a. The spectrum of raw RH showed many characteristic absorption peaks for its content of organic substances such as cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin, and inorganic substances such as silica (SiO2). The broad peak in the RH spectrum at about 3409 cm−1 represents the O-H stretching vibrations. The absorption peak at 2928 cm−1 can be related to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of the C–H aliphatic bonds in the –CH3 and CH2 groups in the structure of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin, respectively. The vibration bands at 1459, 1422, and 1373 cm−1 are due to the -C-H stretching vibrations of the CH2 groups. Besides the vibration caused by adsorbed water molecules, the peak at 1649 cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibrations of -C = O groups in aldehydes and ketones too, while the peak at 1515 cm−1 coincides with the stretched -C-O groups of carboxylates. The peak at 1156 cm-1 represents the C-O stretching of the aliphatic ether. In addition to all of the above, the stretching vibrations of the Si-O-Si groups appear as broad peaks at 1085, 779, 528, and 465 cm−1 [48].Fig. 3
FTIR (a) and XRD (b) spectroscopy of RH and fabricated mesoporous SiO2NPs

It can be inferred from the FTIR spectra displayed for the extracted SiO2NPs in Fig. 3a, with the lower intensity of the peaks related to the organic contents, that the two calcination processes, using temperatures from 600 to 700°C in the presence and absence of citric acid, succeeded in removing the organic matter from the RH. The intensity of the absorption peaks of the extracted SiO2NPs varies with the calcination temperature. Previous reports indicated the possibility of the transformation of amorphous silica into crystalline at higher calcination times and temperatures above 700°C; hence, we used in this study the calcination temperatures of 600 and 700°C [49].

The FTIR spectra of the lyophilized SiO2NPs (S600 and S700, SC600, and SC700) showed vibrational bands at ca. 3445, 2925, 1641, 1553, 1095, 965, 799, and 466 cm−1 consistent with amorphous silica and/or silicic acid, as well as adsorbed moisture [28, 50]. The asymmetric and symmetric vibrational absorption bands of Si-OH appeared at 3445 and 965 cm−1, respectively [51, 52]. The previously estimated adsorbed moisture of 13.10, 13.19, 22.99, and 19.9 wt.% for S600, S700, SC600, and SC700, respectively, via TG analysis, might be the reason for the silanol peak's broadness between 3000 and 3700 cm−1 due to the H-bonded silanol groups. The stretching and bending vibrational peaks corresponding to adsorbed moisture appeared at ca. 3445 and 1641 cm−1, respectively [53]. Further, the symmetric and asymmetric vibrational absorption bands of the Si-O-Si groups from the silicate matrix appeared at ca. 1095 and 799 cm−1, respectively. In addition to bending vibration at ca. 965 and 466 cm−1 [3, 46]. Interestingly, the absence of C=O stretching (C(O)-OH) at 1722 cm-1, C-OH stretching at 1106 cm−1, and CH2 rocking at 779 cm−1 in the FTIR spectra of SC600 and SC700 suggests that citric acid was decomposed during the calcination process [54].

An XRD analysis of RH and SiO2NPs, obtained from RHAs after burning with/without citric acid treatment at 600 and 700°C, was performed to demonstrate the amorphous or crystalline nature of materials under investigation. From Fig. 3b, the main diffraction peaks at Bragg angles (2θ°) of 15.6° and 22.14° of the RH are attributed to the diffraction patterns from the crystal structure of the cellulose content [55]. On the other hand, the broad peak at Bragg angles (2θ°) of ca 22° in the diffraction profiles of the extracted SiO2NPs is characteristic of the amorphous phase of mesoporous SiO2NPs [3, 10]. Hence, the XRD profiles shown in Fig. 3b indicate the successful extraction of amorphous silica by burning RHs at 600 and 700°C. The appearance of a sharp peak at Bragg angles (2θ°) of ca 44° in the diffraction profiles of the raw RH and extracted SiO2NPs can be attributed to the contamination with some impurities [56].

Mesoporous SiO2NPs have received great attention due to their excellent biodegradation and biocompatibility, narrow and tunable pore size distribution, uniform mesoporosity, surface functionalization, flexible morphology, large pore size and surface area, tunable pore diameter (2–30 nm) and particle size (10–1000 nm) [17, 57, 58]. The morphology of the synthesized mesoporous SiO2NPs obtained from RHAs after burning with/without citric acid treatment at 600 and 700°C was explored by employing TEM. As shown in Fig. 4, TEM micrographs reveal single irregular blocks with a width ranging between 160 and 900 nm. These SiO2NPs masses contain spherical, homogeneous, and nearly regular holes and voids with a diameter ranging from 9.06 to 4.02 nm, similar to the mesoporous structures. As a result, the TEM data are consistent with the N2 physisorption isotherm data, where mesoporous are defined as periodic matrices with normal medium-sized pores embedded in an amorphous silica matrix, confirming the successful preparation of mesoporous SiO2NPs. On the other hand, the reduced number of particles visible in the TEM micrographs can be the cause of the relative size discrepancy of mesoporous SiO2NPs between the DLS and TEM examinations.Fig. 4
TEM micrographs of fabricated mesoporous SiO2NPs (a) S600, (b) S700, (c) SC600, and (d) SC700

Further, the morphology of the SiO2NPs differed according to the route used for preparation and the calcination temperature. In the case of SiO2NPs prepared at 700°C and in the presence of citric acid, the particles were more homogeneous and smaller in size, indicating the dependence of the nanostructure formed on both the temperature and the path used for calcination [49, 59].
Characterization of silver-doped mesoporous SiO2NPs

Previous studies have successfully eliminated the defects associated with the chemical synthesis of silver NPs using reducing and stabilizing reagents of ascorbic acid, citrate, elemental hydrogen, and sodium borohydride by exchanging them with naturally occurring biocompatible materials. Generally, plants and their extracts provide an exemplary platform for fabricating bio-silver NPs, as they achieve the scientists' goals of less toxicity, environmentally friendly, easier, safer, and more moderate synthesis procedures [60, 61]. SiO2NPs, extracted from RH, could be a superior model for silver nanoparticle biosynthesis due to their ability to stop the growth of NPs resulting from the possible hydrogen bond network. Also, with surface hydroxyl silanol groups, SiO2 could act as anchor points for silver nanoparticle couplings. Similarly, zeta potential reflects the effective charge on the particles and is related to the electrostatic repulsion between them. Therefore, SiO2NPs with zeta potential in the range of −19.36 to −22.28 mV can be considered closely related to the process of preparing silver NPs and controlling their stability.

Based on the previously mentioned possible roles of SiO2 in the formation of biogenic silver NPs, we can suggest the following mechanism (Fig. 5). Initially, an ion-exchange reaction occurs between silver ions (Ag+), from the solution, and sodium ions bound to the active hydroxyl silanol groups of SiO2NPs. Successively, some of the Ag+ ions are reduced to Ag0 atoms by the reducing groups available on the SiO2NPs surface. These Ag0 atoms then act as nucleation centers and catalyze the reduction of the remaining Ag+ ions in the solution core. After that, metallic nodes are formed by the polymerization of atoms due to fusion. The cycle continues until larger particles with high nuclear energy are assembled. Eventually, the expansion process is halted and firmed by interaction with SiO2 moieties [62].Fig. 5
Schematic of the probable fabrication mechanism for in-situ Ag-doped SiO2NPs

By comparing the FTIR spectra of SiO2NPs with the spectra of silver NPs (Ag-doped SiO2NPs), the same spectral features of varying intensity were observed at varying frequencies (Fig. 6a). These shifts in positions and differences in the intensity of the absorption peaks may result from metal-SiO2NPs interactions. The corresponding absorption peaks of Ag-S600, Ag-S700, Ag-SC600, and Ag-SC700 appeared, respectively, at 3442, 2924, 1634, 1093, 802, and 468 cm−1; 3442, 2923, 1636, 1092, 802, and 469 cm−1; 3436, 2922, 1633, 1095, 804, and 467 cm−1; 3435, 2922, 1632, 1096, 801, and 464 cm−1. This shift in frequencies indicates the interaction and binding of the active moieties of SiO2NPs with silver NPs.Fig. 6
(a) FTIR, and (b) UV-visible spectroscopy of Ag-doped SiO2NPs

Successful fabrication of silver NPs using biogenic-SiO2NPs can be demonstrated through many analytical means. One of them is UV-Vis absorption spectroscopy for defining the composition and stability of fabricated silver-doped SiO2NPs in the aqueous suspension. The UV absorption spectra of silver NPs prepared with different extracted SiO2NPs are shown in Fig. 6b (inset: the optical image of silver-doped SiO2NPs). Variable color tones in prepared samples are attributed to the phenomenon of surface plasmon resonance (SPR). When the conducting electrons on the surface of the NPs are exposed to incident light, they oscillate and the electromagnetic radiation is absorbed by the metal surface. Hence, the formation of silver NPs can be explained by the formation of a broad absorption peak at 420, 418, 408, and 415 nm with a peak width at half-maximum (PWHM) of 143.54, 130.99, 189.82, and 193.23 nm for Ag-S600, Ag-S700, Ag-SC-600, and Ag-SC700, respectively, which is distinctive of SPR from silver NPs. The four silver-doped SiO2NPs' absorption of UV-Vis radiation at different wavelengths and diverse PWHM demonstrates the potential impact of the enhanced mesoporous texture of SiO2NPs on the characteristics of synthesized silver NPs. Thus, as the particles grow to a larger size, the absorption range of the plasmon expands and shifts to higher wavelengths. These results agree well with those obtained previously from the N2 physisorption isotherm.

The XRD diffractograms of silver-doped SiO2NPs, presented in Fig. 7, reveal the diffraction peaks that correspond to the amorphous SiO2 and cubic silver NPs. The appearance of the characteristic amorphous peak from SiO2NPs at 2θ = 22.4, 22.2, 22.43, and 22.46° for Ag-S600, Ag-S700, Ag-SC-600, and Ag-SC700, respectively, indicates that the core of SiO2NPs is not altered or disordered by the in situ synthesized silver NPs. In addition, the silver-doped SiO2NPs showed further diffraction peaks situated at 2θ ca 38, 44, 64, and 77° indexed to the lattice planes of cubic silver NPs at (111), (200), (220), and (311), respectively (Reference code 04-004-6434) [63, 64]. Although the observed lattice plane (200) displays the highest intensity between planes—in contrast to what was provided by the cubic center interface structure of silver NPs—this increased intensity may be due to interference with the Bragg angles (2θ°) of ca 44° caused by impurities from the parent SiO2NPs (see Fig. 3). The interplanar spacing and crystallite size for the as-synthesized silver NPs were estimated using Bragg’s and Scherrer’s formulas, respectively. Table 2 presents the detailed data obtained from the XRD analysis.Fig. 7
XRD spectroscopy of Ag-doped SiO2NPsTable 2

The morphological features of the synthesized Ag-doped SiO2NPs are shown in Fig. 8. TEM micrographs of four Ag-doped SiO2NPs displayed black semi-spherical silver NPs adhered on the surface and in the core to mesoporous grey SiO2NPs. The silver NPs exhibited a relatively wide size distribution extending from 9.03 to 30.47nm, 3.83 to 47.06 nm, 5.79 to 32.80 nm, and 3.37 to 36.71nm in the case of Ag-S600, Ag-S700, Ag-SC-600, and Ag-SC700, respectively. That divergence between the sizes of the four silver NPs, Ag-S600, Ag-S700, Ag-SC600, and Ag-SC700, can be ascribed to the physical and chemical distinctions between the four pristine SiO2NPs as discussed above. The electron diffraction of a selected area analogous to the silver NPs, inset in Fig. 8, exhibited concentric circles with spots of diffraction disseminated about its periphery. These pattern rings are consistent with the cubic silver lattice of (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), and (331) [65–67]. Similar results were observed when chemically synthesized silver NPs were encapsulated in mesoporous SiO2NPs [26].Fig. 8
TEM micrographs of fabricated Ag-doped SiO2NPs (a) Ag-S600, (b) Ag-S700, (c) Ag-SC600, and (d) Ag-SC700

XPS is used to evaluate the sample’s surface chemical states and composition. Table 3 lists the identified elements together with their XPS quantification and binding energies (BE). Through the corresponding binding energies at 533, 369, and 104 eV, the survey spectra of the samples Ag-S600, Ag-S700, Ag, SC-600, and Ag-SC700 in Fig. 9 affirm the presence of oxygen (O 1s), silver (Ag 3d), and silicon (Si 2p), respectively [68, 69]. At 104 eV, the Si 2p high-resolution spectrum can be seen. The typical 3d doublet structure with a doublet splitting of 6 eV is visible in Ag’s high-resolution spectra. The usual Ag (3d5/2) and Ag (3d3/2) doublet at 367.88 and 373.88 eV, respectively, serve as the Ag 3d signal’s defining feature [70, 71]. According to findings in the literature, Ag (0) [Ag (3d5/2)] has a binding energy of 368.0 eV [72]. There are two potential causes for this binding energy shift, one of which is silica particles’ adsorbed Ag+ [70, 73]. The other cause of binding energy shifts from metallic Ag may be related to the change of particle size dimensionality reported in previous works in which the shift to higher binding energy and the expansion of FWHMs are clearly observed with decreasing particle size [72, 74]. Accordingly, XPS results support the successful introduction of silver to the surface of SiO2NPs and demonstrate that SiO2NPs and AgNPs have been efficaciously coupled. Table 3 and Figure 9 make it evident that Ag doped with different extracted SiO2NPs exhibits various binding energies depending on the type of SiO2NPs utilized. In that way, SiO2NPs extracted at 600 °C in the absence and presence of carbon-templated citric acid show higher binding energy and atomic percentage of Si 2p and Ag 3d than their counterparts extracted at 700°C. Therefore, XPS was employed to comprehend how the physical and chemical characteristics of the silica matrix (surface charge, pore size, etc.), which in turn depend on the initial extraction pathway used to extract SiO2NPs, affect the doped silver's chemical formation.Table 3

XPS spectra of fabricated Ag-doped SiO2NPs

Since ancient times, silver metal has been used in medicine for its antimicrobial behavior against many matrices of viruses and organisms (e.g., fungi and bacteria). At present, silver NPs are classified as antimicrobial agents with a wide spectrum. Hence, implementations of silver NPs overcome classical borders and extend to new domains of interest such as clothing, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and luxury. In view of this, the colloids of fabricated silver-doped SiO2NPs were tested against microbial species of Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa as G-, and Bacillus subtilis and Staphylococcus aureus as G+. The disc diffusion agar technique showed different regions of microbial growth suppression by the four Ag-doped SiO2NPs with the tested bacterial species (Fig. 10). Previous studies investigating the efficacy of mesoporous SiO2NPs against several bacterial species found that their activity is similar to that of the control without any added NPs [26]. The bactericidal activity of mesoporous SiO2NPs showed significant development once bonded to silver NPs against all tested microbes. This enhancement in the activity implies that this linking manner could aid in the ability of silver ions to pass through the cell membrane. This association may also enhance the lipophilic nature of the silver atom, thus favoring the infiltration of the cell membrane by the lipid coating, resulting in the impairment of normal cell processes [75, 76]. Furthermore, the bactericidal efficacy was more noticeable for the G+ compared to the G-. The contrast in the potency of the bactericidal activity between the silver-doped SiO2NPs in the experiment could be attributed to the distinctions in the electrostatic interaction between the silver NPs and the mesoporous SiO2NP functional groups. This electrostatic interaction depends on the composition, chemical content, and charge of the mesoporous SiO2NPs [77]. Figure 10 and Online Resource 3 are typical antimicrobial test results for Ag-doped SiO2NPs against Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacillus subtilis, and Staphylococcus aureus as determined by the disc diffusion agar procedure.Fig. 10
Inhibitory zones of fabricated Ag-doped SiO2NPs colloidal suspensions

sec.title: Color strength (K/S) and fastness properties
sec.p: The color strength feature, which is defined as a measure of a dye’s capability to transfer its color to other materials, is indicated by absorption in the visible region of the spectrum, which can be represented as a value of color strength [78]. The obtained results, which represent the color strength (K/S) of the printed fabrics shown in Online Resource 4, reveal that all the printed fabrics have significant K/S values, whether or not they were printed with a paste containing Ag-doped SiO2NPs. Despite this, an improvement in the K/S value was observed when printing polyester fabrics and CO/PET blend fabrics using a paste containing Ag-doped SiO2NPs, while cotton fabrics did not show any significant change. Furthermore, since dye printing is a surface application, the main concern is the abrasion resistance of the print upon washing or rubbing. Supplementary II shows the overall fastness properties of cotton, polyester, and CO/PET screen-printed fabrics with dye printing pastes containing Ag-doped SiO2NPs and those without Ag-doped SiO2NPs. The rubbing test of blank printed samples showed results ranging from moderate to good. But after applying Ag-doped SiO2NPs in the printing paste, enhancement in rubbing values was observed in both dry and wet rubbing tests, which ranged from good to very good in most cases. This may be due to the presence of SiO2NPs on the surface of the fabric, which may increase the surface roughness of the printed fabric and thus improve the resistance of the printed surface to abrasion and rubbing [79]. In addition, regardless of whether Ag-doped SiO2NPs were employed in the printing technique or not, the perspiration, washing, and light fastness qualities for all printed fabrics varied from very good to exceptional.

sec.title: UPF rating
sec.p:
Figure 11 displays UPF values for printed fabrics. According to Australian/New Zealand Standards (AS/NZS-4399-1996), fabrics can be classified according to their UPF value as poorly protected (-) below 20, good (|) from 20 to 29, very good (||) from 30 to 40, and excellent (|||) above 40. That is why it is recommended that the fabric's UPF value be at least 40 to 50 to provide effective protection for human skin from harmful UV rays [79].Fig. 11
UPF of pigment printed fabrics with and without Ag-doped SiO2NPs, where a (CO/PET), b (cotton), c (polyester), and * Ag-doped SiO2NPs

The results showed that cotton and polyester printed fabrics lacking Ag-doped SiO2NPs had low UV protection, whereas the CO/PET printed fabric has a high UV protection property due to its texture composition [21, 79]. In addition to enhancing the protection of the CO/PET blended fabrics to the highest levels by using Ag-doped SiO2NPs (Ag-SC700) paste, an excellent improvement was also made in the protection values of the printed cotton fabrics. This may be due to possible crosslinking between SiO2NPs and cotton fibers in fabrics via surface hydroxyl groups [80]. On the contrary, polyester-printed fabrics showed no improvement. The improvement in the protective efficacy of Ag-doped SiO2NPs-printed fabrics against UV rays may be due to the presence of SiO2NPs that adhere to and coat the surface of the fabrics [21, 81].

Similarly, the EDX mapping of the pigment-printed fabrics with Ag-doped SiO2NPs demonstrate the homogeneous distribution of Ag and Si atoms together with C and O throughout the pigment printed fabric matrix (Fig. 12).Fig. 12
EDX mapping of the pigment printed fabrics with Ag-doped SiO2NPs, where a (CO/PET), b (cotton), c (polyester), and * Ag-doped SiO2NPs

sec.title: Antimicrobial activity of pigment printed fabrics with and without silver-doped SiO2NPs
sec.p:
Antimicrobial activity is one of the required properties in advanced textile industries. Table 4 and Online Resource 5 present the data obtained for the qualitative antimicrobial activity of the treated fabrics. As can be noticed, all fabrics printed with Ag-doped SiO2NPs show enhanced antimicrobial activity against all studied species. The contents of carbon, oxygen, silica, and silver elements in the printed fabric are displayed in Table 4 and Online Resource 6. Despite the variation in the content of silver and silica between cotton and other fabrics, the antimicrobial activity in all the fabrics used in the study does not show much variance between them. Thus, regardless of the fabric type used, the fabrics printed with Ag-doped SiO2NPs have superior antimicrobial activity against G+, G-, and Candida albicans fungi. This microbicidal efficacy obtained for the printed fabrics may be attributed to the penetration of the highly active silver ions through the cell wall membrane of G+ and G-bacteria, causing the leakage of cell contents.Table 4

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Silica NPs have quickly found use in pharmaceuticals, supercapacitors, concrete, optical fibers, and battery materials due to their tunable mechanical, optical, chemical, and physical features. The majority of the time, synthetic organic precursors is used to create high-purity silica. However, this can be an expensive, environmentally harmful, and non-biocompatible process. Alternatives include cheap and plentiful natural silica supplies found in biomass. In this regard, a facile, economic, and scalable extraction technique has been developed to produce SiO2NPs with highly efficient porosity. The presence of citric acid in the dry mixture with rice hull served as a carbon template to control the growth of particles and the porous structure. The temperature applied in the incineration process also has an influential impact on the physicochemical features of as-fabricated mesoporous SiO2NPs. Consequently, four mesoporous SiO2NPs with different pore compositions and pores were obtained from those two extraction routes. Moreover, those prepared mesoporous SiO2NPs showed high efficiency in reducing and stabilizing silver NPs. The technique used, besides being easy and environmentally safe, prevented silver NP agglomeration for extended periods. Finally, the use of silver-doped SiO2NPs in single-pot fabric printing has not only decreased the number of procedures needed for traditional textile finishing but also improved many of its qualities (e.g. antimicrobial activity, UPF, color strength, and fastness).

sec.title: Author contribution
sec.p: Abeer M. Adel, Fatma N. El-Shall, and Mona T. Al-Shemy wrote the main manuscript text. All authors analyzed and interpreted the results, and revised the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.
